final_answer.precision_note: Reported to 3 significant figures, matching the precision of the titration data (0.150 mol dm-3, 23.40 cm3).

method: First convert volumes to dm3: V(NaOH) = 23.40 cm3 = 0.02340 dm3, V(H2SO4) = 25.00 cm3 = 0.02500 dm3. Calculate moles of NaOH: n(NaOH) = c × V = 0.150 mol dm-3 × 0.02340 dm3 = 0.003510 mol. From the balanced equation H2SO4 + 2NaOH → Na2SO4 + 2H2O, the mole ratio of H2SO4 to NaOH is 1:2. Therefore moles of H2SO4 = 0.003510 / 2 = 0.001755 mol. Calculate concentration of H2SO4: c(H2SO4) = n / V = 0.001755 mol / 0.02500 dm3 = 0.0702 mol dm-3.
checks: 2:1 ratio means acid moles are half base moles: 0.00351/2 = 0.001755
Sulfuric acid is diprotic so concentration should be lower than NaOH, which matches
